Title: Linking forum posts -mt-004-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Do lecture quizzes need to be 100% correct for course completion?
Input.posts:
In the first lecture, it is mentioned that all quizzes need to be completed in order to get the course completion certificate. I hoping for some clarity there. If I attempt a quiz and cannot get the answers correct, so I decide to skip it after several attempts, will that prevent me attaining the certificate of completion? For example, the quiz at the end of Lecture zero was very ambiguous and tricky. Is it just what Keith says in the video, or also in the background reading that is assigned right before the quiz? In the reading Keith Devlin says a whole bunch of stuff that fits the question but the correct answer\xA0 was contrary. Though I watched the lecture twice, read the background reading, and furthermore understood it all quite well, I had to result to trying every single possibility in order to get the exact correct answers.
Upvotes:
12
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The course is focused on learning to think a certain way that can and often will lead to 'right' answers. But getting right answers in the course is not crucial. An 'ideal' student who is well prepared for the course and will get a lot out of it will solve about half the problems correctly. Fewer than half and the course is a bit too hard for you; more than half and it's too easy. Getting something right makes us feel good. But we learn only when we get something wrong.
